title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Afghanistan before 1 January 2017?
preds: Affirming forecast for the passage of time.

First published: 19 November 2016, 19:50 IST  25 insurgents, 8 security personnel killed in separate attacks in Afghanistan At least 13 insurgents have been killed, while 17 others were injured in Afghan security forces' ground operations and in air strikes carried out in Afghanistan's Sar-e-Pul province. According to an ANI report, the clearance operation was conducted in Sayad district in which one Afghan security force member was killed and two others were injured and a possible attack on the district center by the Taliban was also neutralized. Meanwhile, local officials said today that seven Afghan policemen were killed in a clash between Afghan security forces and the Taliban in Ghazni province.
Ghazni Police Chief Aminullah Amarkahil said that 12 Taliban insurgents were also killed in the clash that started following Taliban insurgents attacking police check posts in Andar district of Ghazni province.

Taliban is trying to increase influence across the country, however the government controls mostly of the areas and Taliban presence is mostly in rural places "U.S. forces have also been propping up Afghan security forces with hundreds of airstrikes against the Taliban. In June, the Obama administration granted expanded authorities for airstrikes in Afghanistan, allowing U.S. forces to target the Taliban to provide “strategic effects” on the battlefield. In reality, the effects have done just enough to keep the Taliban from holding key territory — such as a district center — for an extended amount of time. Before the summer decision, U.S. air power had been relegated to going after terrorist targets and supporting the defense of U.S. Special Operations forces throughout the country." (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2016/10/14/an-eroding-stalemate-in-afghanistan-as-taliban-widens-its-offensive). EWP has a fairly bizarre definition of targeted killing, I'm not sure if they require killers to have their enemy's names engraved on bullets. Most people in Afghanistan belong to one or other ethnic group, and most groups target each other in revenge killings.  "We saw the UN report as well. Those civilian deaths are awful but do not meet our definition of mass killing as they are not being intentionally targeted as part of a specific group. Let us know if you require further clarification."

“There is no disputing the fact that the wars in Afghanistan and Pakistan continue to be devastating for civilians,” Crawford wrote. “The first six months of 2016 indicate that there is as much or more war-related violence in Afghanistan as in 2015.”
https://news.brown.edu/articles/2016/08/costs-war More than 5,100 civilians have been killed or maimed in the first six months of the year, according to new data from the UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) and the UN Human Rights Office 
https://www.unmultimedia.org/radio/english/2016/07/afghanistan-violence-claims-record-death-toll/ The United Nations says civilian casualties of the war in Afghanistan rose to record levels for the seventh year in row in 2015, as violence spread across the country in the wake of the withdrawal of most international troops.At least 3,545 civilians died and another 7,457 were injured by fighting last year in a four percent increase over 2014, the international organization said in its annual report on civilian casualties.
https://news.vice.com/article/war-related-violence-in-afghanistan-killed-and-injured-more-civilians-than-ever-last-year Rise in Afghan civilian casualties at hands of government forces 
"An increasing number of Afghan civilians are killed and injured at the hands of government forces fighting extremist groups, according to the UN.
A report released on Sunday, documenting the first three months of 2016, shows a 70% rise in civilian casualties caused by pro-government forces, with 127 killed and 242 wounded. "
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/17/rise-in-afghan-civilian-casualties-caused-by-pro-government-forces-taliban

1,601 noncombatants killed in the first six months of 2016, a 4% increase in casualties over the same period the previous year. 
60%  (960) are responsible by anti-government elements (Taliban and ISIS). 
40% (640) - by government and pro-government forces. (this is up 47% compared to the same period last year. 640 for the same time period this coming half of the year would be 640+640=1280, which gives this answer a YES. 
Taliban seem to carry out the majority of the attacks, due to their much greater control of territory, and numbers. I will attribute a conservative 50% of total deaths to Taliban, and 10% of total deaths to IS. Thus IS would be responsible for 160 deaths for that portion of the year. It seems unlikely this will reach 1000 before the years end. 
It’s possible that the numbers of civilians killed by both sides will increase, but as the pro-government forces have already increased much more this year (47%), I doubt they will increase substantially more, in the coming 4 months. Possibly to a 50% increase on last year (Jul – Dec 2015). As such, I will say that 650 people between July and end of Dec will be killed by pro-government forces. That brings the total this year by pro-government forces to 1300, exceeding the mass killing definition. So my answer is Yes, It is likely to occur. But how likely? Over 50%, anyway. We have seen since July, that the US are not removing as many US soldiers from Afghanistan as previously planned, due to rising violence and tensions in Afghanistan. Also, IS and Taliban have formed a shaky peace pact to combat the US and pro-government afghan soldiers… it’s possible that there will be even higher ground fighting – which is what is contributing most to civilian casualties at the moment. That being said, it could also cause a more directed attack against the pro-government forces – or not. Perhaps more co-ordinated suicide attacks.

The Taliban are being pressed and they are known for suicide attacks which might become more likely if they feel desperate.  Also, ISIS is moving in and they will be trying to create conditions as in Syria.  On the other hand, the Afghan Security Forces are in charge of most of the country.  I guess it depends on whether the Afghan Army can hold together.  I guess they will have some initial failures, don't know if they will recover without more US intervention. Also Afghanistan is the Graveyard of Empires.  The number is based on there still being an active conflict, less because some Western nations are helping.

The Diplomat, August 22, 'In Afghanistan, Kunduz Under Siege Once Again - Once again, the Taliban are moving to seize control of the strategic city.': http://thediplomat.com/2016/08/in-afghanistan-kunduz-under-siege-once-again/
Clips from Diplomat article:
"Qala-e-Zal and Ali Abad villages are also contested. “War is going on in Imam Sahib district and Dasht-e-Archi and Chardara, battles expanded in and around Khan Abad and Qala Zal,” said Assadullah Sadat, a member of the Kunduz provincial council.
“It seems that last year’s tragedy is going to happen again,” said another member of the council, Safiullah Amiri, a reference to the collapse of Kunduz city last year.
The Taliban over the weekend have managed to cut off all roads leading into Kunduz. However, as reported by Tolo News, Afghan security forces managed to reopen the Baghlan-Kunduz highway on Saturday. This road serves as a vital corridor linking Kunduz and Kabul and acts as a main artery for sending supplies and reinforcements to the embattled city.
The temporary collapse of Khanabad has displaced hundreds of families and stoked fears that the provincial capital may fall once again. Many of the villagers headed toward Kunduz airport and neighboring Takhar province to escape the violence." Comments: Lowering % by 15 basis points. In aggregate, AF security forces (national army + police + govt. militias) appear better trained and committed, lowering the probability of going rogue. Continuing US & Allied backstop helpful. Taliban and IS remain wild cards.

Thanks @Khalid and @sjens. START's Global Terrorism Database has roughly 10,700 casualties in terror attacks in Afghanistan in 2015, let's guess that half of those were fatalities--5350. Thanks @Khalid and @sjens for the numbers, assuming 1600 for the first half of the year that would be 3200 for the whole year and I'll average that with my GTD-based guess of 5350 for a year of fatalities, (5350 + 3200)/2 = 4275.  There are about four months left before 1 January 2017, 1/12 = .083 * 4 = .332 .  We're approaching the cold part of the year when the weather is less conducive to fighting in Afghanistan so let's downgrade the .332 by .1 to .232. 4275 * .232 = 992 estimated fatalities for a four month time period. Afghanistan is no more stable than it was in 2015. Afghanistan in 2013 and 2014 saw fewer causalities from terror attacks, a lot fewer in 2013, and about 20% fewer in 2014.  I'm guessing around 662 killed in an average four month period over the years 2013-2015.  So if the next four months are reflective of the three year estimated average, this much more likely to resolve as a "No." If the next four months are reflective of the same period in 2015, it's more likely to resolve "Yes" but still likely to resolve as a no. If the next four months are like the first six months of 2016, it's more likely to resolve as a "Yes" but still likely to resolve as a no. https://www.start.umd.edu/gtd/search/Results.aspx?charttype=line&chart=casualties&casualties_type=b&casualties_max=&dtp2=all&country=4

https://unama.unmissions.org/sites/default/files/protection_of_civilians_in_armed_conflict_midyear_report_2016_final.pdf .  (Thanks to @Sjens https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/299866) There were 1601 civilian deaths in the first half of 2016, but about two thirds of them are attributed to anti government elements (probably Taliban) who would not count as a new episode for the purpose of this question. 23% are attributed to pro-government forces ( could be 30%, dividing the 13% jointly attributed to pro and anti government equally between the two). Thus, between January and June, minimun 368 (23% of 1601) maximum 483 (30%) civilians were killed by other than Taliban actions. This suggests between 746 and 968 casualties for the full year.

Saying Yes while hoping for No.   Just about any time frame would justify expectations of a mass killing in Afghanistan.  Unfortunately the odds have grown since the competing anti government groups appear to be willing to stop fighting each other so as to concentrate on knocking out the government.   Thier differences can be settled later.   The American and Europeans appear to be do a slow walk out of the picture.  Their talk of support may continue but the reality is the Afgan government will be on its own to find a peace or take what money they can and fine a safe haven out of the country.   Syria, Iraq and Libya will get what ever attention is offered and Afghanistan will come out on the short end of the stick.

I am very happy that this situation got included. I recently wrote a short paper on Afghanistan and am in regular contact with the German Friedrich Ebert Foundation in Kabul. The situation has gotten worse every month during the past 1-2 years, especially since the Afghanistan version of the Islamic State became active in late 2015. That being said, my risk asessment for a new episode of mass killings is very low. I would like to link to some articles I used in our monitor, but it's down right now. ;-) So I'll link them later. UNAMA keeps a very good quarterly count of civilian casualties. It's also the only one avaiable for Afghanistan, so this has to be THE source to go to for the EWP. This makes this question easier to forecast than others. UNAMA tracks actors and the type of the killing (e.g. fighting, IEDS, targeted killings...). For sake of identifying deliberateley killed civilians, I assume the EWP has to ignore all battle-related deaths. So while the toll of civilians killed by government forces has increased, these sometimes disturbing numbers won't resolve this question. There are targeted killings (warcrimes) comitted by gov. forces, e.g. by the tribal militias used by the gov., that would count. But they should not come close to resolve this question. This leaves us with the Islamic State in Afghanistan. The Islamic State in Afghanistan has risen to prominence by applying the same tactics that they use elsewhere: Using brutal force and displaying their brutality very publicly.  They started off with killing tribal elders in the South-East by forcing them to sit down on landmines and then let them explode remotely. The IS distributed the video locally. This was an unprecedented move - even for Afghanistan. They continued on with some middle-scale and one large-scale terror attack. If they will archieve the capability, I am very sure that they will resolve this question. Their aim seems to be to demonstrate that they are more effective than the Taliban. However, while they indeed recruited a bunch of extremist Taliban fighters, they mainly consists of foreigners and indeed alinate the local population by attacks such as the one against the very respected tribal elders. The whole point of the Taliban ist their local Pashtun identity combined with their very strong Afghan national values. The IS just cannot provide that. The only angle of the IS is that they "get things done". SO far, the US and the Afghan gov. moved  very strongly against the IS as soon as it proclaimed their Afghan version. And so did the Taliban. The IS is therefore being confronted with multiple enemys. For the IS to resolve this question, it needs to grow stronger and it needs to convince a larger number of Talibans to join their cause. I don't see this happening in this timeframe. I might overrate the patience and loyality of the different Taliban elements however. There are conflicts inside the different Taliban and they grow increasingly frustrated. That would be the hole the soft spot has to push into. My low forecast does not render this question dispensable, as this by itself, would be a valuable risk assessment. If it's correct. ;) Edit: Of course there is the possibility that the IS and the Taliban might join forces, especially since ex-Taliban members that joined the IS should still have some contact to their ex-fellow fighters and they got a big common enemy. While this very well might occur from time to time locally, I don't expect a broader and lasting alliance between the two, because their aims and means are just too different. See the article by @aaseawaf15 down below.

With a new interpretation of 'mass-killing' i reduce my projection to below 50%. Either a new target needs to be undertaken by the taliban or a different organization needs to target a civilian group. Something I find hard to pin down is how broad are the 'groups'? Can there be overlap between 'groups' e.g. could one civilian death be counted in multiple targeted groups? With how things stand, the anti-govt forces are attributed with 60% of civilian deaths (~960), if there is currently an ongoing mass killing, then the number of killings that could be attributed to a NEW mass killing goes down. By how much? Depends on overlap between groups... shot in the dark - 50% (480 left to count towards new). Projecting that to the end of year gives 960, which is not a new mass killing, but this does not account for possibilties of state-led mass killing, a risk, but less likely than one by Taliban (how much? idk). The UN report also noted a decrease in 'targeted and deliberate' killings. This combined with the overarching theme of fewer global mass-killings in recent history pushes me below 50%. I would go lower if not for the high uncertainty in the region.

Going below consensus, thanks to Khalid for comments
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/299747

I'm well below consensus here. This is because any mass killing by the Taliban will not be considered a new episode, and only killings of those "not a current member of a formal or irregular military organization" will count. That leaves civilian fatalities caused by the IS/Daesh, or in error by the state.

Looking at the recent past, I speculated mass killing in Afghanistan to be a Poisson random variable with mean 3. Thus, the conditional probability of there being three or more mass killings this year given there have all ready been two is about 0.72.

Comments: Current situation highly suggests so.

Early Warning Project shows mass killings in 2015 as a continuation all the way from 2013. UN report shows increased killing of civilians, however, there is a considerable increase in killing of civilians by pro-gov't and coalition forces, while it is unlikely these groups will kill enough civilians in a manner that satisfies (feel very weird saying it like that) the EWP criteria, the rise in deaths should probably not be taken as sure-thing evidence in support of continued mass killing status.
